Ralf Krakow=
ski writes: 
> Hi, 
> I wonder if there is a preferd way to use JUnit with =
EJB in 
> your opinion? 
> What is best practice and have anyone used any e=
xtensions like JUnitEE 
> ( http://www.infohazard.org/junitee/ <http://www.=
infohazard.org/junitee/>
) or j2eeunit 
> ( http://j2eeunit.sourceforge.net=
/ <http://j2eeunit.sourceforge.net/> )? 

The various extensions to JUnit d=
o not test EJBs. They test servlets, which
may in turn talk to EJBs. Person=
ally, I find this distasteful. My major
objection to it is that, with most =
EJB servers (including WebLogic), having
to repackage and redeploy EJBs to =
run the tests just takes too long.

What I do is write my tests like this: =


public void testSomething() { 
  MyObject obj =3D obtainMyObject(); 
  ..=
. 
} 

obtainMyObject() is a "smart" function. When running in 'live' mode,=
 it
obtains a JNDI context and retrieves the EJB remote interface. When run=
ning
in 'local' mode, it returns an instance of the EJB class directly. So =
I have
the same batch of tests running in a local mode and a non-local mode=
.

This makes my life a lot easier. My test cycle is a lot shorter, and tha=
t
makes me feel good. My "local" tests don't give me 100% confidence; the
l=
ocal version has no security, no transactions, nor anything else provided
b=
y the container. However, it gives me about 90% confidence that my business=

logic works. Then, when I run the test in 'live' mode (which I do as part =
of
my integration work), I get the extra 10%.

> Any tips regarding using V=
isual Cafe and Weblogic 6 with 
> junit would be 
> great. 

Yeah; don't us=
e Visual Cafe. :) 

I plan to write up a proper paper on this subject at so=
me point (assuming I
get a round tuit, of course). 

Robert.
